title: Stored XSS in https://app.mopub.com

profile.name: Twitter
profile.about: Twitter helps you create and share ideas and information instantly, without barriers.

vulnerability_information: **Vulnerable URL** https://app.mopub.com/reports/custom/ **XSS Payload:** "> **Parameter** nrnew-interval ## Steps To Reproduce: 1. Login with your credentials. 2. Go to URL: https://app.mopub.com/reports/custom/ 3. Click on New Network Report => Create a new network performance report. 4. Start Burp suite proxy and intercept on. 5. vulnerability_information_html:
Vulnerable URL
https://app.mopub.com/reports/custom/

XSS Payload:
"><img src=x onerror=alert(domain)>

Parameter
nrnew-interval

Steps To Reproduce:

  1. Login with your credentials.
  2. Go to URL: https://app.mopub.com/reports/custom/
  3. Click on New Network Report => Create a new network performance report.
  4. Start Burp suite proxy and intercept on.
  5. Click on Run and Save button. intercept the request.
  6. Enter above payload in vulnerable parameter.
  7. You will notice that xss will execute.

POST Request

POST /reports/custom/add_network_report/ HTTP/1.1
Host: app.mopub.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:65.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/65.0
Accept: */*

X-Requested-With: XMLHttpRequest
Content-Type: multipart/form-data; boundary=---------------------------68352596720712
Content-Length: 838
Connection: close

activities.message:
Thank you for your report @todaytoday.

While we were able to reproduce the behavior in your report, we would like some clarification on the security impact of this behavior. It appears that since the report with the XSS payload is **not** saved, the JavaScript can only be executed against the user delivering the XSS payload, is this correct? Can you confirm if it is possible to perform attacks using this behavior against **other** MoPub users?

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security.
activities.markdown_message:
Thank you for your report @todaytoday.

While we were able to reproduce the behavior in your report, we would like some clarification on the security impact of this behavior. It appears that since the report with the XSS payload is not saved, the JavaScript can only be executed against the user delivering the XSS payload, is this correct? Can you confirm if it is possible to perform attacks using this behavior against other MoPub users?

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security.

activities.message:
Hi @bugtriage-ryan,

Correction : Stored XSS to Reflected XSS 

I apologized its my mistake, it's Reflected XSS and its can be execute for once after inject the javascript payload, and it have same impact what have impact of another Reflected XSS 

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Cross-site_Scripting_(XSS)

## Reflected XSS
``Reflected attacks are those where the injected script is reflected off the web server, such as in an error message, search result, or any other response that includes some or all of the input sent to the server as part of the request. Reflected attacks are delivered to victims via another route, such as in an e-mail message, or on some other website. When a user is tricked into clicking on a malicious link, submitting a specially crafted form, or even just browsing to a malicious site, the injected code travels to the vulnerable web site, which reflects the attack back to the user’s browser. The browser then executes the code because it came from a "trusted" server. Reflected XSS is also sometimes referred to as Non-Persistent or Type-II XSS. ``

Hope you understand, what i want to say, let me know if you have any questions.

Thanks :)
activities.markdown_message:

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Cross-site_Scripting_(XSS)

Reflected XSS

Reflected attacks are those where the injected script is reflected off the web server, such as in an error message, search result, or any other response that includes some or all of the input sent to the server as part of the request. Reflected attacks are delivered to victims via another route, such as in an e-mail message, or on some other website. When a user is tricked into clicking on a malicious link, submitting a specially crafted form, or even just browsing to a malicious site, the injected code travels to the vulnerable web site, which reflects the attack back to the user’s browser. The browser then executes the code because it came from a "trusted" server. Reflected XSS is also sometimes referred to as Non-Persistent or Type-II XSS.

Hope you understand, what i want to say, let me know if you have any questions.

Thanks :)

activities.message:
Thank you for the clarification @todaytoday.

While we can confirm that reflected XSS is indeed occurring here, we would also like some further clarification to get a better idea of the full impact of your report. Typically, reflected XSS is leveraged to execute arbitrary JavaScript on behalf of other users.  [OWasp's documentation](https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Cross-site_Scripting_(XSS) states that payloads are usually delivered to a victim.

>  Reflected attacks are delivered to victims via another route, such as in an e-mail message, or on some other website. When a user is tricked into clicking on a malicious link, submitting a specially crafted form, or even just browsing to a malicious site, the injected code travels to the vulnerable web site, which reflects the attack back to the user’s browser.

However, in this case, it appears that the JavaScript is reflected to the user that is injecting the JavaScript into the POST request, and that the resulting report is **not** saved. Can you clarify how this behavior can be used by an attacker to execute arbitrary JavaScript on behalf of a victim? That is, is it possible to use this behavior to generate a link, report, etc. that a victim can then access, which will result in the arbitrary JavaScript to be executed in the victim's browser?

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security.
activities.markdown_message:
Thank you for the clarification @todaytoday.

While we can confirm that reflected XSS is indeed occurring here, we would also like some further clarification to get a better idea of the full impact of your report. Typically, reflected XSS is leveraged to execute arbitrary JavaScript on behalf of other users. [OWasp's documentation](https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Cross-site_Scripting_(XSS) states that payloads are usually delivered to a victim.

Reflected attacks are delivered to victims via another route, such as in an e-mail message, or on some other website. When a user is tricked into clicking on a malicious link, submitting a specially crafted form, or even just browsing to a malicious site, the injected code travels to the vulnerable web site, which reflects the attack back to the user’s browser.

However, in this case, it appears that the JavaScript is reflected to the user that is injecting the JavaScript into the POST request, and that the resulting report is not saved. Can you clarify how this behavior can be used by an attacker to execute arbitrary JavaScript on behalf of a victim? That is, is it possible to use this behavior to generate a link, report, etc. that a victim can then access, which will result in the arbitrary JavaScript to be executed in the victim's browser?

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security.

activities.message:
Hi @bugtriage-ryan, 

Thanks for Responding. 
Can you please explain which type of Information you required for Identify or Resolve the Vulnerability.?

And if you are asking regarding Reflected XSS Impact then for that as a normal behavior. it should be required to inject malicious JavaScript every time. in this application attacker can't be execute JavaScript remotely. user need to add on the Web application request. 

Hope you understand, what i want to explain.  Let me know if you need any other details regarding this. i really happy to provide that.  

Thanks :)

activities.message:
Thank you for your report. We believe it may be a valid security issue and will investigate it further. It could take some time to find and update the root cause for an issue, so we thank you for your patience.

Thank you for helping keep Twitter secure!
activities.markdown_message:
Thank you for your report. We believe it may be a valid security issue and will investigate it further. It could take some time to find and update the root cause for an issue, so we thank you for your patience.

activities.message: Thank you for bringing this issue to our attention. Unfortunately, this report does not fall in scope for a monetary reward at this time. However, you will still be listed in our Hall of Fame. As a reminder, please remember to keep the details of this report private until we have fully investigated and addressed the issue.
